<p><strong>Electric avenues:</strong> if you’re driving a car that needs to be fueled up, chances are your vehicle runs on an internal-combustion engine (ICE), powered by gasoline or diesel fuel. Electric vehicles (EVs) have a battery instead of a gasoline tank and an electric motor instead of an ICE. </p>
<p>But not all EVs are created equal. There are several types of EVs, all powered a little differently:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em><a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/improving-battery-electric-vehicle-profitability-through-reduced-structural-costs">Battery electric vehicles (BEVs)</a> </em>are powered by rechargeable electric batteries. BEVs produce <a href="https://www.epa.gov/greenvehicles/explaining-electric-plug-hybrid-electric-vehicles">no tailpipe emissions</a> and have no combustion engine.</li>
    <li><em>Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs)</em> are powered by an electric motor as well as a <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/a-new-segmentation-for-electric-vehicles">small combustion engine</a>. They have an all-electric range from 20 to 60 miles and can be charged at a charging station.</li>
    <li><em>Hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) </em>have an internal-combustion engine and an electric motor that assists only at low speeds. The battery is charged either by the combustion engine or through recuperation when braking. </li>
    <li><em>Fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs) </em>use electric motors. The electricity is <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/how-hydrogen-combustion-engines-can-contribute-to-zero-emissions">generated in fuel cells</a> and can be stored in a small buffer battery. Fuel cell vehicles require hydrogen (compressed into tanks) as fuel. </li>
</ul>
<p>The automotive future is electric—McKinsey projects that <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric">worldwide demand for EVs</a> will grow sixfold from 2021 through 2030. Annual unit sales would go from 6.5 million to roughly 40 million over that period. In recent years, the COVID-19 crisis and the war in Ukraine have accelerated the momentum of sustainable mobility. <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric">Understanding EVs and e-mobility</a> can illustrate how these vehicles are transforming the industry and helping to decarbonize the planet. </p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients">Automotive and Assembly Practice</a>.</em></p>
<h2>Are there other EVs aside from cars?</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>The popularity of electric bikes and <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-e-kickscooter-takes-to-the-road-understanding-consumer-ownership-preferences">scooters</a>, driven by their affordability and ease of access, represents a new chapter in <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-micromobility-is-here-to-stay">micromobility</a>. </p>
<p>On the opposite end of the EV spectrum are <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-most-etrucks-will-choose-overnight-charging">e-trucks</a>. Demand for them is booming in response to a regulatory push to <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/road-freight-global-pathways-report">reduce emissions in the logistics and transport sectors</a>. EU regulations now require new trucks to reduce carbon emissions 30 percent by 2030. California’s recent Advanced Clean Truck regulation requires manufacturers of commercial vehicles to start selling e-trucks in 2024 and restricts all sales of new trucks to electric models by 2045.</p>
<p>Today, e-trucks are becoming more economical for manufacturers to produce and for consumers to purchase and own. As a result of improvements in electric powertrain technology and declining battery costs, McKinsey predicts that within the next few years, the <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-most-etrucks-will-choose-overnight-charging">total cost of ownership</a> for many e-trucks, depending on the specific use case, will be similar to or better than that of traditional ICE trucks. Toward the end of this decade, we expect that fuel cell electric trucks, powered by hydrogen, will also penetrate the commercial-vehicle industry, especially in heavy-duty applications and long-haul use cases, where pure battery electric powertrains might have limitations given battery size and weight. </p>
<p>And in the broader world of mobility, <a href="/featured-insights/the-next-normal/air-taxis">electric aircraft</a> are also on the horizon. Electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) aircraft could be flying above cities <a href="/featured-insights/the-next-normal/air-taxis">as soon as 2030</a>. The global electric-aircraft market is estimated to reach $17.8 billion by the year 2028, <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/global-electric-aircraft-market-hit-093600938.html?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAGqMMwGMjrcfS1Qj31-uYXmPwCpmu22ZeOsOyFr34xLKtjNv4v9ppLdz4-6ktI76P6Gnl9MufIYZVkbOQjhVdcfTdwuNV_Zx4Cl5BSLnqGD-AuEmuLWxcVlcZu0H_LJMaJfYDeYadosYYVq6-lX5mx5HOIOQbsDoEazMqLKiK2-C">according to a recent report</a>. Funding for advanced air mobility, including electric aircraft, <a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/up-in-the-air-how-do-consumers-view-advanced-air-mobility">exceeded $8 billion</a> as of March 2021. </p>
<h2>What is the range of EVs?</h2>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons___eQy6"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="Expandable Sidebar" type="button" id="button_id" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__toggle-btn__EL8iE" aria-expanded="false" data-layer-event-prefix="UI Item" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-category="sidebar" data-layer-subcategory="open" data-layer-text="open sidebar"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--radial___y3csX_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-xxl___cL3ZT_990311c mck-plus-no-circle-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the McKinsey Center for Future Mobility</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>These insights were developed by the McKinsey Center for Future Mobility (MCFM). Since 2011, the MCFM has worked with stakeholders across the mobility ecosystem by providing independent and integrated evidence about possible future-mobility scenarios. With our unique, bottom-up modeling approach, our insights enable an end-to-end analytics journey through the future of mobility—from consumer needs to modal mix across urban and rural areas, sales, value pools, and life cycle sustainability. <a href="mailto:mmip@mckinsey.com">Contact us</a>, if you are interested in getting full access to our market insights via the McKinsey Mobility Insights Portal.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Range is how far an EV can go before recharging, an important consideration for customers in the market for EVs. That’s because, at present, most EVs can travel only around <a href="https://www.caranddriver.com/shopping-advice/a32603216/ev-range-explained/">half the distance</a> of the typical ICE vehicle before recharging—and because <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/can-the-automotive-industry-scale-fast-enough">charging stations are still few and far between</a>, even in markets that have embraced EVs. </p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients">Automotive and Assembly Practice</a>.</em></p>
<h2>What is fast charging for EVs?</h2>
<p>There are two types of chargers:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Alternating current (AC) slow charging (3–22 kW)</em> provides energy for, on average, 30 miles for an hour of charging. These are found in private homes and in public charging stations. AC is also used in private homes and can be installed easily.</li>
    <li><em>Direct-current (DC) fast charging (50–300 kW) </em>provides, on average, at least 150 miles for 20 minutes of charging. This type of charging is available only at public charging stations and requires a significant investment to install.</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/ev-fast-charging-how-to-build-and-sustain-competitive-differentiation">Fast chargers are a considerable expense</a>—as of 2022, the hardware alone for a 300-kW charger costs from $50,000 to $100,000, and installation can be just as pricey. The costs could drop by about 40 percent over the next five to seven years as demand for fast charging increases to reflect the expanding EV customer base. The greatest opportunity in the EV-charging value chain will come from on-the-go charging, which allows drivers to pay a premium to charge within an hour.</p>
<p><a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/can-the-automotive-industry-scale-fast-enough">Accelerating the rollout of charging infrastructure</a> will be a crucial enabler for EVs to go mainstream. At present, there are about 1.15 million public charging stations in China, around 340,000 in Europe, and roughly 100,000 in the United States. The European Electric Vehicle Charging Infrastructure Masterplan, developed together with industry associations (including ACEA, Eurelectric, and WindsEurope), forecasts that until 2030 approximately 7,000 charging stations must be built every week to sustain the ramp-up of e-mobility.</p>
<p>Governments, utilities, and charging companies need to consider several questions as they build out the <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/can-the-automotive-industry-scale-fast-enough">charging infrastructure</a>. For instance, where should charging stations be located—bearing in mind accessibility, convenience, and <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/building-the-electric-vehicle-charging-infrastructure-america-needs">equity</a>? What charging speed is essential? And what’s the best way to balance profitability and convenience?</p>
<h2>How do EVs affect the electric grid? </h2>
<p>As the mobility market continues to shift toward EVs, many observers are considering the effects on global energy grids. Generally, electrical capacity will need to expand to support the growing number of EVs on the roads, but analysis suggests that <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-potential-impact-of-electric-vehicles-on-global-energy-systems">growth in e-mobility will not drive substantial increases in power demand</a> in the short to medium term. </p>
<p><a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-impact-of-electromobility-on-the-german-electric-grid">McKinsey’s research on EVs in Germany</a>—where up to 15 million EVs are expected to be on the roads by 2030—suggests that the majority of charging will take place at single- or multiunit homes, places of work, on highways and at public stations, and at retail destinations such as shopping malls. The greatest opportunities for growth will be at van or truck fleet hubs, which will need to evolve to meet both heavy demand and the need for fast charging.</p>
<p>One solution to mitigate much of the impact of EV customers on electric grids is “<a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric">managed charging</a>.” That approach entails a combination of incentives for customers to use off-peak charging times and moves to enable utilities to turn charging on and off for areas or individuals, based on real-time use. <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/charging-electric-vehicle-fleets-how-to-seize-the-emerging-opportunity">Vehicle-to-grid (V2G)</a> technology can facilitate managed charging. </p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients">Automotive and Assembly Practice</a>.</em></p>

<h2>How does the rise of EVs affect natural resources? </h2>
<p>Ecological concerns are central to the shift to EVs—for consumers as well as regulators. </p>
<p>The rise of EVs has direct implications for the supply chain of raw materials. The greater demand for EVs in recent years has meant <a href="/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/the-raw-materials-challenge-how-the-metals-and-mining-sector-will-be-at-the-core-of-enabling-the-energy-transition">greater demand for raw materials and EV inputs</a>, including metals and ores such as cobalt, <a href="/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/lithium-mining-how-new-production-technologies-could-fuel-the-global-ev-revolution">lithium</a>, and nickel. Demand for lithium carbonate, for example, could rise to three million to four million metric tons in 2030, from 500,000 metric tons in 2021. As for nickel, McKinsey predicts a shortage in the middle of this decade. Exploding demand for nickel, as well as its use in several industries (such as steel production), is likely to drive this shortage. </p>
<p>Of course, fewer ICE vehicles in operation means less demand for oil and natural gas. </p>
<p>More broadly, when it comes to sustainability and the mobility industry, much attention is paid to <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-zero-carbon-car-abating-material-emissions-is-next-on-the-agenda">bringing down tailpipe emissions</a>—understandable, since they account for 65 to 80 percent of the emissions automobiles generate. But it’s worth noting that efforts to reduce material emissions will be crucial, over time, to realizing the potential of the <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-zero-carbon-car-abating-material-emissions-is-next-on-the-agenda">zero-carbon car</a>. <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/mobilitys-net-zero-transition-a-look-at-opportunities-and-risks">Mobility’s longer-term net-zero transition</a> entails both opportunities and risks, and coordinated responses from the public and private sectors can help ease the shift.</p>
<h2>Is the automotive future electric? </h2>
<p>Simply put, yes. <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric">Mainstream EVs will transform the automotive industry</a> and help decarbonize the planet. There is essentially no other solution to decarbonize passenger transport. Hydrogen will probably not play a significant role in passenger mobility as EV-charging speeds and ranges increase and green hydrogen remains too expensive for the average private BEV owner. Other options have different limitations: synthetic fuels are too expensive, biofuels are not abundantly available—and both release emissions. </p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Regulation.</em> National and municipal governments have introduced new regulations and incentives to accelerate the shift to sustainable mobility. In the United States and Europe, new regulatory targets aim for an EV share of 50-plus percent by 2030. A number of countries, including those in the European Union, have gone well beyond this, announcing accelerated timelines for ICE sales bans in 2030 or 2035. Many national governments are also <a href="https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2021/06/electric-vehicles-financial-incentives/">offering EV subsidies</a>. </li>
    <li><em>Consumer behavior. </em>People are more accepting than ever of alternative, sustainable mobility options. In 2021, the number of inner-city trips with shared bicycles and e-scooters rose by 60 percent year over year. Interest in EVs reflects this consumer shift: <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric">more than 45 percent of car customers in 2021</a> considered buying an EV.</li>
    <li><em>Technology. </em>Automotive-industry players are accelerating the development of new concepts of mobility, including <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-irresistible-momentum-behind-clean-electric-connected-mobility-four-key-trends">electric, connected, autonomous, and shared vehicles</a>. These technology innovations will help reduce the cost of EVs and make electric shared mobility a real alternative to owning a car.</li>
</ul>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients">Automotive and Assembly Practice</a>.</em></p>
<h2>Are EVs profitable? How can companies boost the profitability of EVs? </h2>
<p><a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability">EV profitability</a> remains at best slightly above breakeven for current models, although three-quarters of EVs analyzed show negative profit margins. This is mainly the result of high battery costs and expensive R&D efforts over still relatively low volumes.</p>
<p>But the market share for EVs is rising. McKinsey’s analysis forecasts that if this continues, the average <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability">EV profit level will gradually improve</a> thanks to cost reductions and economies of scale. Already, Tesla posted a <a href="https://www.counterpointresearch.com/tesla-revenue-reached-record-high-of-18-8-billion-during-q1-2022/#:~:text=Keeping%20parity%20with%20vehicle%20sales,also%20been%20on%20the%20rise.#:~:text=Keeping%20parity%20with%20vehicle%20sales,also%20been%20on%20the%20rise.">32 percent gross margin in Q1 2022</a>.</p>
<p>For now, companies have ways to boost the profitability of EVs. These include <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability">incremental measures</a> to spread industry best practices (such as <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-new-key-to-automotive-success-put-customer-experience-in-the-drivers-seat">direct-to-customer sales</a> or <a href="/capabilities/operations/how-we-help-clients/product-development-procurement/design-to-value">design-to-value</a> processes) to optimize costs. Automakers can also make more <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability">radical adjustments</a> to their business models—for instance, by incorporating EV/battery-as-a-service offerings.</p>
<p>Reducing battery costs (despite increasing raw-material costs) through economies of scale, innovations in battery technology, and a better charging infrastructure (to avoid always-increasing range requirements) will help improve the cost position of electric vehicles. </p>
<h2>How are chip shortages affecting the EV market?</h2>
<p>A <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/coping-with-the-auto-semiconductor-shortage-strategies-for-success">shortage of semiconductors</a>, also known as chips, is affecting the vehicle market—electric and otherwise. The shortage is the result of a complicated confluence of events, including struggles during the COVID-19 pandemic, a lack of new capacity, geopolitical tensions, limited stock, and contract terms unique to the auto industry. The scarcity lowers car production and is responsible for billions of dollars of lost revenue.</p>
<p>Given the shortage and resulting losses, <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/coping-with-the-auto-semiconductor-shortage-strategies-for-success">automotive EV-component manufacturers</a> will need to rethink how and when they order semiconductors to meet the growing demand for EVs.</p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients">Automotive and Assembly Practice</a>.</em></p>
<h2>How can ICE businesses stay competitive?</h2>
<p>The last hundred years are known in the automotive industry as the ICE Age, when vehicles with internal-combustion engines dominated the roads and skies. While most vehicles on the road are still powered by ICEs today, EVs are slowly replacing ICE vehicles, especially in the European Union, China, and the United States. However, emerging markets will still use ICE vehicles into the 2040s, and aftermarket components will still be used through the 2050s and beyond.</p>
<p>To stay competitive, ICE suppliers need to <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/ice-businesses-navigating-the-energy-transition-trend-within-mobility">explore ways to navigate the energy transition—and revisit their portfolios</a>—as electric mobility continues to grow.</p>
<h2>What is the Electric Vehicle Index? </h2>
<p>McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/mckinsey-electric-vehicle-index-europe-cushions-a-global-plunge-in-ev-sales">Electric Vehicle Index (EVI)</a> tracks the dynamic e-mobility market in 15 countries, focusing on BEVs and PHEVs. It emphasizes two key factors: </p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Market demand,</em> by analyzing the share of EVs in the overall market and the factors fueling the growth and adoption of EVs in each country. These factors include incentives (such as subsidies), existing infrastructure, and the range of available EVs. </li>
    <li><em>Industry supply,</em> by examining how many of a country’s manufacturers are producing EVs and EV components, such as e-motors and batteries.</li>
</ul>
<p>The EVI then assesses the key performance indicators in each country’s EV market and plots them on a scale from 0 to 5 for both supply and demand factors. The <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/mckinsey-electric-vehicle-index-europe-cushions-a-global-plunge-in-ev-sales">resulting analysis</a> offers interesting insights on the regional dynamics and emerging trends of EVs. </p>
<p><em>For a more in-depth exploration of these topics, see insights from the <a href="/features/mckinsey-center-for-future-mobility/our-insights">McKinsey Center for Future Mobility</a>. </em></p>

id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"What is an EV","displayName":"What is an EV","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"00c77d3d-345d-4365-b052-4aaaf840af39","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"What is an EV?"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"What is an EV (Electric Vehicle)?"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"EVs are vehicles powered by electricity and an electric motor rather than a conventional gasoline-fueled internal-combustion engine."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"In this McKinsey Explainer, we explore what an electric vehicle (EV) is, how they impact the environment, and the future of the automotive industry."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-02-06T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Image 1]]\n[[audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eElectric avenues:\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;if you\u0026rsquo;re driving a car that needs to be fueled up, chances are your vehicle runs on an internal-combustion engine (ICE), powered by gasoline or diesel fuel. Electric vehicles (EVs) have a battery instead of a gasoline tank and an electric motor instead of an ICE. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut not all EVs are created equal. There are several types of EVs, all powered a little differently:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/improving-battery-electric-vehicle-profitability-through-reduced-structural-costs\"\u003eBattery electric vehicles (BEVs)\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/em\u003eare powered by rechargeable electric batteries. BEVs produce \u003ca href=\"https://www.epa.gov/greenvehicles/explaining-electric-plug-hybrid-electric-vehicles\"\u003eno tailpipe emissions\u003c/a\u003e and have no combustion engine.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePlug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs)\u003c/em\u003e are powered by an electric motor as well as a \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/a-new-segmentation-for-electric-vehicles\"\u003esmall combustion engine\u003c/a\u003e. They have an all-electric range from 20 to 60 miles and can be charged at a charging station.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) \u003c/em\u003ehave an internal-combustion engine and an electric motor that assists only at low speeds. The battery is charged either by the combustion engine or through recuperation when braking. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs) \u003c/em\u003euse electric motors. The electricity is \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/how-hydrogen-combustion-engines-can-contribute-to-zero-emissions\"\u003egenerated in fuel cells\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and can be stored in a small buffer battery. Fuel cell vehicles require hydrogen (compressed into tanks) as fuel. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe automotive future is electric\u0026mdash;McKinsey projects that \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric\"\u003eworldwide demand for EVs\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will grow sixfold from 2021 through 2030. Annual unit sales would go from 6.5 million to roughly 40 million over that period. In recent years, the COVID-19 crisis and the war in Ukraine have accelerated the momentum of sustainable mobility. \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric\"\u003eUnderstanding EVs and e-mobility\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can illustrate how these vehicles are transforming the industry and helping to decarbonize the planet. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eAutomotive and Assembly Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAre there other EVs aside from cars?\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe popularity of electric bikes and \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-e-kickscooter-takes-to-the-road-understanding-consumer-ownership-preferences\"\u003escooters\u003c/a\u003e, driven by their affordability and ease of access, represents a new chapter in \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-micromobility-is-here-to-stay\"\u003emicromobility\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the opposite end of the EV spectrum are \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-most-etrucks-will-choose-overnight-charging\"\u003ee-trucks\u003c/a\u003e. Demand for them is booming in response to a regulatory push to \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/road-freight-global-pathways-report\"\u003ereduce emissions in the logistics and transport sectors\u003c/a\u003e. EU regulations now require new trucks to reduce carbon emissions 30 percent by 2030. California\u0026rsquo;s recent Advanced Clean Truck regulation requires manufacturers of commercial vehicles to start selling e-trucks in 2024 and restricts all sales of new trucks to electric models by 2045.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eToday, e-trucks are becoming more economical for manufacturers to produce and for consumers to purchase and own. As a result of improvements in electric powertrain technology and declining battery costs, McKinsey predicts that within the next few years, the \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-most-etrucks-will-choose-overnight-charging\"\u003etotal cost of ownership\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for many e-trucks, depending on the specific use case, will be similar to or better than that of traditional ICE trucks. Toward the end of this decade, we expect that fuel cell electric trucks, powered by hydrogen, will also penetrate the commercial-vehicle industry, especially in heavy-duty applications and long-haul use cases, where pure battery electric powertrains might have limitations given battery size and weight. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd in the broader world of mobility, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-next-normal/air-taxis\"\u003eelectric aircraft\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;are also on the horizon. Electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) aircraft could be flying above cities \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-next-normal/air-taxis\"\u003eas soon as 2030\u003c/a\u003e. The global electric-aircraft market is estimated to reach $17.8 billion by the year 2028, \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/global-electric-aircraft-market-hit-093600938.html?guccounter=1\u0026amp;guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8\u0026amp;guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAGqMMwGMjrcfS1Qj31-uYXmPwCpmu22ZeOsOyFr34xLKtjNv4v9ppLdz4-6ktI76P6Gnl9MufIYZVkbOQjhVdcfTdwuNV_Zx4Cl5BSLnqGD-AuEmuLWxcVlcZu0H_LJMaJfYDeYadosYYVq6-lX5mx5HOIOQbsDoEazMqLKiK2-C\"\u003eaccording to a recent report\u003c/a\u003e. Funding for advanced air mobility, including electric aircraft, \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/up-in-the-air-how-do-consumers-view-advanced-air-mobility\"\u003eexceeded $8 billion\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as of March 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat is the range of EVs?\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eRange is how far an EV can go before recharging, an important consideration for customers in the market for EVs. That\u0026rsquo;s because, at present, most EVs can travel only around \u003ca href=\"https://www.caranddriver.com/shopping-advice/a32603216/ev-range-explained/\"\u003ehalf the distance\u003c/a\u003e of the typical ICE vehicle before recharging\u0026mdash;and because \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/can-the-automotive-industry-scale-fast-enough\"\u003echarging stations are still few and far between\u003c/a\u003e, even in markets that have embraced EVs. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eAutomotive and Assembly Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat is fast charging for EVs?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two types of chargers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAlternating current (AC) slow charging (3\u0026ndash;22 kW)\u003c/em\u003e provides energy for, on average, 30 miles for an hour of charging. These are found in private homes and in public charging stations. AC is also used in private homes and can be installed easily.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDirect-current (DC) fast charging (50\u0026ndash;300 kW) \u003c/em\u003eprovides, on average, at least 150 miles for 20 minutes of charging. This type of charging is available only at public charging stations and requires a significant investment to install.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/ev-fast-charging-how-to-build-and-sustain-competitive-differentiation\"\u003eFast chargers are a considerable expense\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;as of 2022, the hardware alone for a 300-kW charger costs from $50,000 to $100,000, and installation can be just as pricey. The costs could drop by about 40 percent over the next five to seven years as demand for fast charging increases to reflect the expanding EV customer base. The greatest opportunity in the EV-charging value chain will come from on-the-go charging, which allows drivers to pay a premium to charge within an hour.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/can-the-automotive-industry-scale-fast-enough\"\u003eAccelerating the rollout of charging infrastructure\u003c/a\u003e will be a crucial enabler for EVs to go mainstream. At present, there are about 1.15 million public charging stations in China, around 340,000 in Europe, and roughly 100,000 in the United States. The European Electric Vehicle Charging Infrastructure Masterplan, developed together with industry associations (including ACEA, Eurelectric, and WindsEurope), forecasts that until 2030 approximately 7,000 charging stations must be built every week to sustain the ramp-up of e-mobility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments, utilities, and charging companies need to consider several questions as they build out the \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/can-the-automotive-industry-scale-fast-enough\"\u003echarging infrastructure\u003c/a\u003e. For instance, where should charging stations be located\u0026mdash;bearing in mind accessibility, convenience, and \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/building-the-electric-vehicle-charging-infrastructure-america-needs\"\u003eequity\u003c/a\u003e? What charging speed is essential? And what\u0026rsquo;s the best way to balance profitability and convenience?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow do EVs affect the electric grid? \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs the mobility market continues to shift toward EVs, many observers are considering the effects on global energy grids. Generally, electrical capacity will need to expand to support the growing number of EVs on the roads, but analysis suggests that \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-potential-impact-of-electric-vehicles-on-global-energy-systems\"\u003egrowth in e-mobility will not drive substantial increases in power demand\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the short to medium term. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-impact-of-electromobility-on-the-german-electric-grid\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s research on EVs in Germany\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;where up to 15 million EVs are expected to be on the roads by 2030\u0026mdash;suggests that the majority of charging will take place at single- or multiunit homes, places of work, on highways and at public stations, and at retail destinations such as shopping malls. The greatest opportunities for growth will be at van or truck fleet hubs, which will need to evolve to meet both heavy demand and the need for fast charging.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne solution to mitigate much of the impact of EV customers on electric grids is \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric\"\u003emanaged charging\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026rdquo; That approach entails a combination of incentives for customers to use off-peak charging times and moves to enable utilities to turn charging on and off for areas or individuals, based on real-time use. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/charging-electric-vehicle-fleets-how-to-seize-the-emerging-opportunity\"\u003eVehicle-to-grid (V2G)\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;technology can facilitate managed charging. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eAutomotive and Assembly Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up mckinseyexplainers]]\n\u003ch2\u003eHow does the rise of EVs affect natural resources? \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEcological concerns are central to the shift to EVs\u0026mdash;for consumers as well as regulators. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe rise of EVs has direct implications for the supply chain of raw materials. The greater demand for EVs in recent years has meant \u003ca href=\"/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/the-raw-materials-challenge-how-the-metals-and-mining-sector-will-be-at-the-core-of-enabling-the-energy-transition\"\u003egreater demand for raw materials and EV inputs\u003c/a\u003e, including metals and ores such as cobalt, \u003ca href=\"/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/lithium-mining-how-new-production-technologies-could-fuel-the-global-ev-revolution\"\u003elithium\u003c/a\u003e, and nickel. Demand for lithium carbonate, for example, could rise to three million to four million metric tons in 2030, from 500,000 metric tons in 2021. As for nickel, McKinsey predicts a shortage in the middle of this decade. Exploding demand for nickel, as well as its use in several industries (such as steel production), is likely to drive this shortage. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf course, fewer ICE vehicles in operation means less demand for oil and natural gas. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore broadly, when it comes to sustainability and the mobility industry, much attention is paid to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-zero-carbon-car-abating-material-emissions-is-next-on-the-agenda\"\u003ebringing down tailpipe emissions\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;understandable, since they account for 65 to 80 percent of the emissions automobiles generate. But it\u0026rsquo;s worth noting that efforts to reduce material emissions will be crucial, over time, to realizing the potential of the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-zero-carbon-car-abating-material-emissions-is-next-on-the-agenda\"\u003ezero-carbon car\u003c/a\u003e. \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/mobilitys-net-zero-transition-a-look-at-opportunities-and-risks\"\u003eMobility\u0026rsquo;s longer-term net-zero transition\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;entails both opportunities and risks, and coordinated responses from the public and private sectors can help ease the shift.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eIs the automotive future electric? \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimply put, yes. \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric\"\u003eMainstream EVs will transform the automotive industry\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and help decarbonize the planet. There is essentially no other solution to decarbonize passenger transport. Hydrogen will probably not play a significant role in passenger mobility as EV-charging speeds and ranges increase and green hydrogen remains too expensive for the average private BEV owner. Other options have different limitations: synthetic fuels are too expensive, biofuels are not abundantly available\u0026mdash;and both release emissions. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRegulation.\u003c/em\u003e National and municipal governments have introduced new regulations and incentives to accelerate the shift to sustainable mobility. In the United States and Europe, new regulatory targets aim for an EV share of 50-plus percent by 2030. A number of countries, including those in the European Union, have gone well beyond this, announcing accelerated timelines for ICE sales bans in 2030 or 2035. Many national governments are also \u003ca href=\"https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2021/06/electric-vehicles-financial-incentives/\"\u003eoffering EV subsidies\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsumer behavior. \u003c/em\u003ePeople are more accepting than ever of alternative, sustainable mobility options. In 2021, the number of inner-city trips with shared bicycles and e-scooters rose by 60 percent year over year. Interest in EVs reflects this consumer shift: \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric\"\u003emore than 45 percent of car customers in 2021\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;considered buying an EV.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTechnology. \u003c/em\u003eAutomotive-industry players are accelerating the development of new concepts of mobility, including \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-irresistible-momentum-behind-clean-electric-connected-mobility-four-key-trends\"\u003eelectric, connected, autonomous, and shared vehicles\u003c/a\u003e. These technology innovations will help reduce the cost of EVs and make electric shared mobility a real alternative to owning a car.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eAutomotive and Assembly Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAre EVs profitable? How can companies boost the profitability of EVs? \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability\"\u003eEV profitability\u003c/a\u003e remains at best slightly above breakeven for current models, although three-quarters of EVs analyzed show negative profit margins. This is mainly the result of high battery costs and expensive R\u0026amp;D efforts over still relatively low volumes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut the market share for EVs is rising. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s analysis forecasts that if this continues, the average \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability\"\u003eEV profit level will gradually improve\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;thanks to cost reductions and economies of scale. Already, Tesla posted a \u003ca href=\"https://www.counterpointresearch.com/tesla-revenue-reached-record-high-of-18-8-billion-during-q1-2022/#:~:text=Keeping%20parity%20with%20vehicle%20sales,also%20been%20on%20the%20rise.#:~:text=Keeping%20parity%20with%20vehicle%20sales,also%20been%20on%20the%20rise.\"\u003e32 percent gross margin in Q1 2022\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor now, companies have ways to boost the profitability of EVs. These include \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability\"\u003eincremental measures\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to spread industry best practices (such as \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-new-key-to-automotive-success-put-customer-experience-in-the-drivers-seat\"\u003edirect-to-customer sales\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;or \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/how-we-help-clients/product-development-procurement/design-to-value\"\u003edesign-to-value\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;processes) to optimize costs. Automakers can also make more \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability\"\u003eradical adjustments\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to their business models\u0026mdash;for instance, by incorporating EV/battery-as-a-service offerings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReducing battery costs (despite increasing raw-material costs) through economies of scale, innovations in battery technology, and a better charging infrastructure (to avoid always-increasing range requirements) will help improve the cost position of electric vehicles. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow are chip shortages affecting the EV market?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/coping-with-the-auto-semiconductor-shortage-strategies-for-success\"\u003eshortage of semiconductors\u003c/a\u003e, also known as chips, is affecting the vehicle market\u0026mdash;electric and otherwise. The shortage is the result of a complicated confluence of events, including struggles during the COVID-19 pandemic, a lack of new capacity, geopolitical tensions, limited stock, and contract terms unique to the auto industry. The scarcity lowers car production and is responsible for billions of dollars of lost revenue.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven the shortage and resulting losses, \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/coping-with-the-auto-semiconductor-shortage-strategies-for-success\"\u003eautomotive EV-component manufacturers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will need to rethink how and when they order semiconductors to meet the growing demand for EVs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eAutomotive and Assembly Practice\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow can ICE businesses stay competitive?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe last hundred years are known in the automotive industry as the ICE Age, when vehicles with internal-combustion engines dominated the roads and skies. While most vehicles on the road are still powered by ICEs today, EVs are slowly replacing ICE vehicles, especially in the European Union, China, and the United States. However, emerging markets will still use ICE vehicles into the 2040s, and aftermarket components will still be used through the 2050s and beyond.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo stay competitive, ICE suppliers need to \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/ice-businesses-navigating-the-energy-transition-trend-within-mobility\"\u003eexplore ways to navigate the energy transition\u0026mdash;and revisit their portfolios\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;as electric mobility continues to grow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat is the Electric Vehicle Index? \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/mckinsey-electric-vehicle-index-europe-cushions-a-global-plunge-in-ev-sales\"\u003eElectric Vehicle Index (EVI)\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;tracks the dynamic e-mobility market in 15 countries, focusing on BEVs and PHEVs. It emphasizes two key factors: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMarket demand,\u003c/em\u003e by analyzing the share of EVs in the overall market and the factors fueling the growth and adoption of EVs in each country. These factors include incentives (such as subsidies), existing infrastructure, and the range of available EVs. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIndustry supply,\u003c/em\u003e by examining how many of a country\u0026rsquo;s manufacturers are producing EVs and EV components, such as e-motors and batteries.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe EVI then assesses the key performance indicators in each country\u0026rsquo;s EV market and plots them on a scale from 0 to 5 for both supply and demand factors. The \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/mckinsey-electric-vehicle-index-europe-cushions-a-global-plunge-in-ev-sales\"\u003eresulting analysis\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;offers interesting insights on the regional dynamics and emerging trends of EVs. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eFor a more in-depth exploration of these topics, see insights from the \u003ca href=\"/features/mckinsey-center-for-future-mobility/our-insights\"\u003eMcKinsey Center for Future Mobility\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about
